text: Do all important business accounts require a second step at sign-in, such as a one time code on a telephone application?
hint: This extra step is called multi factor authentication and it prevents many common attacks.

text: Is your guest wireless network separate from the business wireless network used by company devices?
hint: Separating guests from business devices reduces the chance of attacks.

text: Does each person have their own login and password for business systems, rather than sharing accounts?
hint: Shared accounts make it hard to track and control access.

text: Are administrator rights limited to people who truly need them for their job?
hint: Fewer administrator accounts reduce the damage from mistakes or attacks.

text: Are accounts for staff or contractors removed on the same day they leave?
hint: Quick removal prevents misuse of leftover access.

text: Do laptops and telephones used for work have a screen lock with a password or personal identification number?
hint: Screen locks protect information if a device is lost or left unattended.

text: Is full device encryption turned on for company laptops and, where supported, for telephones?
hint: Encryption protects data if a device is lost or stolen.

text: Is reputable endpoint protection software installed and active on all computers?
hint: Endpoint protection helps block and detect harmful software.

text: Are important business files backed up automatically to a separate location such as a cloud service or external drive?
hint: Backups protect against device loss, damage, and harmful software.

text: Have you tested restoring a backup in the last six months to confirm it actually works?
hint: A tested backup gives confidence during an emergency.

text: Are operating system updates turned on to install automatically on all devices?
hint: Automatic updates close known security holes quickly.

text: Are commonly used applications such as web browsers, document tools, and email clients updated automatically?
hint: Applications often include important security fixes in updates.

text: Is the office router password changed from the factory default and is remote administration disabled unless truly needed?
hint: Default passwords and open management panels are easy targets.

text: Is the router or wireless access point kept up to date with the latest firmware from the vendor?
hint: Router updates fix security bugs that attackers target.

text: Have staff been shown simple ways to spot suspicious messages and links in the last six months?
hint: Short awareness refreshers reduce the chance of someone clicking a harmful link.

text: Do people know who to contact first if something suspicious happens, such as a harmful message, lost device, or unusual payment?
hint: Clear reporting helps contain problems quickly.

text: Is access to cloud folders limited to only those who need it for their work?
hint: Limiting access reduces the chance of accidental or harmful sharing.

text: Are links to share files set to expire or restricted to named people whenever possible?
hint: Expiring or restricted links reduce exposure of shared data.

text: Are social media and advertising accounts protected with an extra sign-in step and stored in a password manager rather than being shared by message?
hint: Central, safe storage and a second step prevent lockouts and takeovers.

text: Do you have a simple one page checklist of first steps to take during a cyber incident, such as isolating a device, changing passwords, and who to notify?
hint: A short checklist reduces stress and speeds up response when something goes wrong.
